subject: Re: Can a font with an unfree character be free?
body:
On 5/14/07, Don Armstrong <don@debian.org> wrote:
On Mon, 14 May 2007, Nathan Edgars II wrote:> On 5/14/07, Don Armstrong <don@debian.org> wrote:> >Considering the fact that the actual symbol is a white wheelchair on a
> >blue background, it's not clear that a black font would be a                        
^^^^^^^^^> >derivative work of such a design.   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^> I didn't think simply changing colors removed the original copyright.[emphasis added]If that is in fact what was done, it obviously doesn't.
However, what is actually copyrighted is a specific representation ofa person in a wheelchair, and the creation of derivative worksthereof. It's not clear that all minimalistic representations of a
person in a wheelchair would be derivative works of the ISA.
But a depiction with the same lines in the same place would be unfree,
right? You'd have to basically start from scratch and draw a new
wheelchair symbol to make it free?
